thread.title: The Labor Party tones down its support for the US alliance
thread.title_full: The Labor Party tones down its support for the US alliance | afr.com

author: Tony Walker
title: The Labor Party tones down its support for the US alliance
text:
Julia Gillard's cloying speech to the US Congress in March 2011 bore the imprint of an American public relations agency flack. Gary Ramage Share on twitter by Tony Walker While the Labor Party ties itself in knots over the great wedge issue of asylum seeker politics, its triennial national conference this weekend in Melbourne will seek to contemporise its foreign policy to accommodate a changing global and regional environment.
In the longer term, this would seem better use of the party's time and energy than haggling over turnbacks, but whether a modernising of Labor's foreign policy platform gets much attention in the midst of one of the party's great existential debates will be another matter.
By prevaricating on the asylum seeker issue until the last moment before Conference, the party had managed to "salami slice itself into oblivion", as a prominent figure on the left put it.
How this issue was left to fester until conference eve tells you more than you need to know about a feckless Bill Shorten leadership.
Labor will debate "Australia's place in a changing world" this Sunday, in which a modernised platform will be adopted, including its most significant alteration.
This comes in Clause 40 of Chapter 11. Such a proposed change gets rid of reference to the ANZUS Treaty as "one of Australia's great national assets" – like the Barrier Reef or the Melbourne Cricket Ground or Ayers Rock.
In its place are the words: "The United States remains our closest security ally, formalised through the ANZUS Treaty, and a vital global partner."
This is juxtaposed with clause 43 which describes the "re-emergence of China" as "one of the most significant developments of the 21st century".
 'Deepen, extend' engagement The draft platform commits Labor to "deepen and extend" Australia's engagement with China.
This would seem to get the balance right between what was no doubt calculated in previous platforms to be a "wedge-proof" description of Labor's unalloyed commitment to the American alliance, and the modern reality of the need to balance Australia's security and economic interests.
This is common sense.
Labor foreign affairs spokeswoman Tanya Plibersek should be given credit for simplifying and contemporising the party's foreign policy platform to make it both more relevant and more readable.
Plibersek tells AFR Weekend that changes to the section dealing with the ANZUS alliance were aimed at emphasising a relationship that was "strong, long and deep but not compliant".
"This is a good place for Labor to be," she says.
Declarations of undying regard for a great and powerful friend, mirrored in the previous platform, reached their apotheosis, or nadir – depending on your point of view – under the Julia Gillard premiership.
Ingratiating speech Gillard's cloying speech to Congress on March 10, 2011 bore the imprint of an American public relations agency flack, aimed not at asserting Australia's values and interests but at ingratiating ourselves with Congressional representatives, insofar as they were interested.
Congress was hardly a full house that day.
Foreign aid activists at the national conference will be disappointed there is no reference in the draft platform to the aspirational goal of 0.7 per cent of gross national income as Australia's contribution to development assistance, in line with millennium goals.
Nor is there is a hard and fast commitment to a notional 2 per cent of GDP expenditure on defence.
Plibersek's explanation for the above omissions is that because the policy document represents a "broad statement of principles and values" it would not have made sense to clutter it with too much detail.
This will not satisfy the foreign aid lobby.
Support for Palestinian state Labor's draft platform contains obligatory support for a "two-state" solution in the Arab-Israel dispute and for Israel to live within secure internationally recognised borders and agreed by the parties.
It also commits Labor to support for a Palestinian state, but the wording falls short of that being demanded by Labor activists, including former foreign minister Bob Carr.
A slew of resolutions in state ALP conferences, calling for sterner action to penalise Israel for its settlement-building activities and recognition of a Palestinian state, will add to pressures on conference this weekend to stiffen the anodyne wording of the Palestine section.
A senior Labor figure tells me that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's provocative statements during the recent Israeli election, that he would not countenance a Palestinian state while he was in office, has further soured Labor attitudes.
Shorten, identified with what internal critics describe as the "Likud faction" of the Victorian branch, will have his hands full with the Left on asylum seekers. One assumes he will not want a fight on the vexed Palestine issue.
Tony Walker is The Australian Financial Review 's international editor.
